All that has been said is that the Mimi is generally accurate in filming these seven elements of the 1956 platform, with some warnings. With regard to federal assistance to low-income communities, the 1956 Platform for Action stated that the Party "will fully promote the Republican-sponsored rural development programme to expand operations, increase the income of low-income families on farms and assist tenant farmers." With regard to social security protection, the programme has extended social security coverage by the Eisenhower Administration to 10 million additional workers, and increases in benefits for 6.5 million Americans. With regard to refugees, the programme highlighted the Department's work in sponsoring the Refugee Relief Act "to provide asylum to thousands of refugees, expelled and displaced persons," promising "full support" for further efforts. Ms. Christine Anderson, historian of the University of Javier, noted that many refugees came from communist countries in Eastern Europe, so this was not a particularly controversial issue during the cold war period. With regard to the minimum wage, the Platform notes that the Eisenhower Administration has raised the minimum wage to more than 2 million workers. He urged that the protection of the minimum wage should be extended "to as many workers as possible and as practical." With regard to the improvement of the unemployment benefit system, the 1956 Platform for Action doubled the actions taken by the Administration to provide unemployment insurance to an additional 4 million workers and to support efforts to "improve the effectiveness of the unemployment insurance system." The 2012 platform does not specifically deal with refugees, but with migration. He criticizes President Barack Obama for having established an "unrecognized amnesty programme" (f) by granting permission to workers to illegal foreigners. He also states that "the granting of amnesty is only rewarded and encourages further breaches of the law" and undertakes "to establish humanitarian procedures to encourage illegal aliens to return to their homes voluntarily, while enforcing the law against those who exceed their visas." The 2012 platform does not specifically mention the minimum wage, but focuses on business practices in the free market rather than government regulation of labour markets, which blames the weak economic recovery in the country for "the unprecedented uncertainty in the American free enterprise system due to the overall policies of the current administration." Even taking into account the delicate differences in the 1956 Platform for Action, the clearest difference between the two platforms for action may be in their approach to trade unions. Our "Mimi" rule says that the Republican Party Platform 1956 supports equal pay, minimum wage, asylum for refugees, protection of trade unions, etc. This is generally true. It should be noted, however, that other elements of the 1956 Platform for Action were considered conservative for that era. Some issues also changed significantly between 1956 and 2012, such as the shift from a focus on post-war refugees to an emphasis on irregular migration. The claim is accurate but requires further clarification or information, and therefore we often evaluate it correctly.
